events.text:
* One of the most fundamental parts 
  of the human experience.

* These three sections determine how
  we live our lives, so much so that
  we don't even think about it!

It is
perfectly
natural for
human brains
to see it
this way.

We don't really think too much about
how time works.

By making sense of time, we could
view it more directly.

There are a few
different ways to
visualize time.

One of the most common
being a timeline.

-> This is a line on which we
   place events.

* Anything that occurs in our
  universe

We can mark events by
displaying their
duration on our
timeline.

This divides our
timeline into three 
sections.

But how do we decide
what is /before/,
and what is /after/?

On a general line, this 
would be entirely arbitrary.

On a timeline, these words 
have clear meanings relating 
to causality.

Could not have
possibly caused it ->

The fact that the rock fell
is /immutable/; it can't be
changed past this point ---->

Could not have been
caused by the rock ->
falling

<- Tree being destroyed
   by falling rock
   (caused by rock
   falling)

<- Rock slides down 
   cliff (caused the 
   rock to fall)

We can formalize
this by assigning
numbers to our
events.

Now, we have a way
of determining
whether a given
event is before
another.

We can't definitively say
which one is before another.

This gives us the concept of
/points/ in time.

We can always directly
compare these by just
comparing their numbers.

We can also test whether a
given point of time is
during an event.
This gives us two temporal objects:

* Represents a process with a
  start, middle and end.

So, what does time feel like for the 
actors immersed in it?

-> Around this present are two
   regions, the /past/ and the 
   /future/.

One of the most important
things about these regions
is we have /knowledge/
about the past, but not
about the future.

We might be able to
extrapolate, but we can't
/know/.

-> This knowledge of the past also
   usually degrades over time.

-> We're also not just pure observers
   to events in the future; we can 
   take a part in them and change the 
   outcome. But we can't do that to 
   events in the past.

Most of this should be pretty
obvious if you've lived in the
universe at all...

But the reason I'm explaining all
of this is so we have a firm
understanding of what happens
/here/, before we explore
somewhere...

So far, we've been considering a
single line of time and its one- and
zero-dimensional subspaces.

But what if we
were to... add
another axis?

but what does it
actually like,
mean tho?

Remember how we needed just one number
to represent a point in time?

The difference between a regular line
and a timeline is /causality/.

What does causality mean when you have
two time directions?

-> Extrapolating from current known
   laws of physics you get a
   structure where time dimensions
   can be rotated into eachother.

-> Greg Egan's Dichronauts has the
   extra time dimension act as a
   space dimension with weird
   rotation rules

I'm not gonna be doing either of
those.

Visually, this means
that a is to the left of
b, below b, or both.

Before we continue, let's give some
names to these axes for clarity.

If you're familiar with 4D spatial
nomenclature, you'll know that the
names for the two new spatial
directions are:

To follow convention, I'm going to
coin the two new words for the two
new time directions from Greek as
well:

Total past; things
that happened and
can't be changed.

Total future;
things that will
happen and that
you can affect.

Partial future;
things that have
not occured yet,
but you can't
currently affect.

Partial future;
things that have
not occured yet,
but you can't
currently affect.
How are these two time dimensions different?

Since this is a worldbuilding* project and
not a physics one, I'll describe this from
the perspective of the actors in the
universe.

-> Along the lateral time axis, generally go
   slower and encounter more resistance.

-> Along the vertical time axis, things are
   more fluid.

The reason such a distinction is even 
necessary is because if both time axes 
worked in the exact same way, then the same 
exact events would happen on both, and so 
they'd be indistinguishable, basically 
collapsing into a single time dimension.

Events now take up a two-dimensional
/area/

For example, let's say a rock falls
like before.

Here I'm using a rectangle as
its shape, but keep in mind
it could be something else.

Remember how we had three
regions before? Now we have
nine!

Total past: anything that
started the event must've
occured here.

Can affect the event while
it's ongoing, but could not
have started it

In a partial future, so these
can not affect the event.

Total future: after event is
fully completed

Time shadow: the event has
partially terminated (can not
still be affected) but the
outcome is still unknown.

Time shadows extend
to the end of time;
for the infinite
history that will
occur in them, the
outcome is still
unknown.

As such, in something like a
conversation, one would want to reduce
the time shadow as much as possible.

It turns out the if the event is
rectangle-shaped, the shape that causes
the minimal time shadow is a square.

Now that we've mentioned what 
both points and areas are, we 
can go to revisit lines.

It seems that they only 
represent the beginning or end 
of an event, analagous to what 
points do in one dimension.

-> However lines don't really 
   seem to exist in isolation, 
   unlike points in 
   one-dimensional time.

Time during which a ball
is being thrown into the
air.

Ball hits the ground and 
falls into a hole.

Ball hits the ground and
stays there.

Then, another person goes
to pickup the ball
katopin-after it is
thrown.

Only one thing can occur after two
events on different time axes.

So whatever happens
     and            
      must lead up
to   .

This also
means that
there's a
limit on
what you can
do on either
time axis;
it must lead
up to the
same thing
in the end.

Of course, that isn't the /real/ name, since the
real name isn't pronounceable in our 3+1
dimensional spacetime.

Of course, we don't have the normal
phonemes you would encounter in a
mere single dimension of time.

There's a whole host of things you
could do for this.

I opted to take the phonemes we
already have, and use two of them to
create our two-dimensional phonemes.

Each of these sub-phonemes is called
a <component>, and there's the
lateral component and the vertical
component, written with a slash.
e.g (t/p = t as lateral
           p as vertical)

Effectively, what occurs here is that
the mouth is articulating one
component in one direction, and the
other component in the other
direction.

p

p'

t

t'

This is a little different from the ones you may be used to, so let me explain
what this even means.

V
e
r
t
i
c
a
l

For example, p/t is
allowed, because its
corresponding cell has an
O,

but h/f isn't, since
its corresponding cell has
an X.

We have a mostly three vowel system (or 9 
vowel system since every combination is a 
valid phoneme) but with the addition of /ə/.

The schwa is used to make previously 
unpronounceable segments pronounceable.

This is actually /very very/ common. It
shows up at least once in pretty much every
word, with only a few exceptions.

C
  CCC
 C C
CCC
CC

Of course, we have two time
dimensions, so this is
two-dimensional as well.

Phonemes katopin of another
are written right of the
phoneme, meanwhile phonemes
after are written above.

A unique part of working in two time
dimensions is that often you will want to
rotate words along the two time dimensions
in order to save space.

(to be technical, when I say /rotate/, I'm
 actually referring to a reflection over the
 diagonal)

Keen observers might've noticed that the
phonology is not symmetric; a phoneme like
p/l is allowed, but l/p is not.

This means that when a word is rotated, its
phonemes under go Rotation Mutation; a
process by which phonemes disallowed by the
phonology are turned into allowed phonemes.

This is a rather simple
process; each disallowed
phoneme is mapped to an allowed
phoneme, according to this
table.

p/s  -> p/f
p'/s -> p'/p'
t/s  -> t/f
t'/s -> t'/t'
k/s  -> k/f
k'/s -> k'/k'
m/s  -> m/f
f/s  -> f/f
p/ʂ  -> p/l
p'/ʂ -> p’/l
t/ʂ  -> t/l
t'/ʂ -> t'/l
k/ʂ  -> k/l
k'/ʂ -> k'/l
m/ʂ  -> m/l
f/ʂ  -> f/l
l/p  -> f/p
l/p' -> p'/p'
l/t  -> f/t
l/t' -> t'/t'
l/k  -> f/k
l/k' -> k'/k'
l/m  -> f/m
l/f  -> f/f
l/s  -> f/s

- Saj is a mostly analytic language with some
  fusional elements.

- Sentences can either be lateral or vertical;
  a lateral sentence has the next word katopin
  from the previous, while vertical sentences
  have the next word be after.

- Lateral sentences use words as-is, while
  vertical sentences use /rotated/ words.

Here I'm using a
pretty lose definition
of adjective/adverb,
because things like
verb conjugations or
the locative particle
occupy the A space.

There's a total of 36 different verb conjugations
for every subject-tense combination.

Note that * all imply  the 
continuous aspect.

For the other tenses, the
continuous aspect can be
marked manually with this
word:

And the perfective aspect
can be marked with this:

ə/ə	k'/k'	ə/ə
ə/ə	t/t	i/u	p/t
m/f	t/t	ə/ə

There are sometimes two or three
temporal variations of words where
we'd usually expect one in our linear
languages.

-> For example, the word for <then>
   has three variants:

These are used
depending on
the position of
the sentence
relating to the
previous.

When there's
ambiguity, any
are allowed.
So, let's look at the name of the language.

-> I've been calling it Saj during this video,
   but that's a crude linearized approximation
   of what the actual name is.

a/i			
k'/p'	a/i		

ə/ə			
m/f	a/i		ə/ə
s/f	s/l	a/i	j/j

So overall, the name means something like
"saying" or "speech" or "language".

To get the linearized name <Saj>, I just took
the bottom row of this word.

Of course, you could take any row here,
giving different results.

Or you could slice it vertically, giving
<Fəp'i>
So let's try to translate a simple phrase:

We'll make this a lateral sentence; so
sentence flow goes from prin to katopin.

For the past tense, we'll use the prin-past
tense (aka the absolute past tense).

Saj is a pro-drop language, so that means
that we can exclude the subject entirely
because it will be covered by the verb
conjugation.

ə/ə		
ə/ə	l/l	ə/ə	f/f	ə/ə	
f/l	ə/a	p/k	s/k'	k/l	ə/ə
k'/p'	p/t	k/f	ə/ə

The position of the word marked with the
locative particle matters; if we placed at
the font of the sentence like this:

ə/ə		
ə/ə	l/l	ə/ə	f/f	ə/ə	
f/l	ə/a	p/k	s/k'	k/l	ə/ə
k'/p'	p/t	k/f	ə/ə

-> We must place at the end, where it means
   "I walked /to/ school."

Each sentence here can be pretty decently translated into
a single sentence in a linear language, like English.

Star also means <god> in Saj, since
they worship the stars.

From here, the passage branches off
into two, as is common in many Saj
stories because it makes optimal use
of the time given.

PLUR
all	      GNO	 3SG.AN
environment	create light

Using a pronoun as an adjective
signifies ownership.

PLUR		
3SG.AN    GNO    PROA
character reveal location

COP.R	all.R	
god.R	GNO	    two
SUB	determine part

So this sentence is both in the future of 
the one before and the one prin, so it can 
rely on information from both of them.

These rotate the entire subordinate clause, 
and then place it in the new direction.

God in the singular is shorthand for all
of them.

This sentence synthesized info
from the previous two sentences
in both time directions.

-> Each of those described two
   parts, and now we mention
   those two parts.

While we could translate this
linearly by putting these
sentences next to eachother, it
would get akward when we try to
do more than just this part.

So there's not really a good place to put   if you try to
translate this into a linear language.

And it gets even worse when you try to insert   which
builds on everything before and prin it.

While linear translations are
possible for arbitrary Saj text,
they completely destroy the flow
of the original, and it's pretty
much impossible to reconcile.

What we are effectively doing
when translating to a linear
language is mapping each of
these points onto a line.

In an ideal scenario, we would 
want to do this in a way that 
preserves causality.

-> So if an event is before or
   prin another event, it should 
   be before it on our final 
   timeline.

(remember, this is what it means for a point
to be before or prin another point)
We wanna map this relation to

( ) should be before  ( ) if and only if
  is before or prin

We also want   to be a /bijection/, meaning
every sentence should be mapped to a unique
point in the resultant timeline.

-> This is because we can't say two
   sentences at the same time.
So, can we construct this transformation?
Let's say we have this magical transformation  .

Now we know that  ~  is true if and only if
 ( ) <  ( )

Therefore NOT  ~  is true if and only if
 ( ) >=  ( )
Since  ~  is false, that must mean that    >=   .
Since  ~  is false, that must mean that    >=   .
The only way this can be true is if    =   .
Since   is a bijection, this must mean that   =  .
However if we look at   and  , they are not equal!

* This is a contradiction and it means that this
  magical function   does not exist.

This result shows that we can not translate Saj
into a linear language in a sensible way; it also
sort of tells us /why/ that's true.

-> In a timeplane you can have events that are at
   different times, but not strictly before or
   after eachother.

-> This is impossible to do on a timeline, so we
   can not map a timeplane onto a timeline while
   keeping its structure intact.

* Saj uses a bijective base eight
  system: a system in which zero is
  not written.

To see how this works, let's look at
something a little more familiar:
One hundred and one is written X1

X2
X3
X4
X5
X6
X7
X8
X9
XX

However instead of bijective
base ten, Saj uses bijective
base /eight/.

-> Which is similar, except
   we have digits from one
   to eight.

-> So we have a one's place,
   an eight's place, a
   sixty-fours place, and so
   on.

Saj numbers are written as a digit 
and then a particle representing the 
place of that number.

These particles
replace the ə/ə
phonemes on the
side of the
number.

As well as that, Saj has a built-in way to 
represent two-dimensional vectors, since these 
are needed in everyday communication.

-> For example, if you wanted to say something 
   like "Let's meet in (2,7) hours."

The way you would do this is to take the 
lateral component and interlace it with the 
rotated form of the vertical component.

ə/ə	m/f	ə/ə
h/h		t/p
	p/k	ə/ə

This leads to an overlapping vowel, which can
be resolved by just getting rid of the
vertical component's vowel.

And there you go! A single word for (2,7). You
can do the same process for any two numbers.

Saj is written with a logographic
writing system; every word is
written with a single glyph.

The language is read left-to-right
on the lateral time axis, and
bottom-to-top on the vertical (the
same way we've been writing the
phonetic transcription)

You may notice that this writing
system looks pixelated; this is
because most writing is done on
tablets with blocks that can be
placed on the down or up position.

Symbols may also be rotated 90°
clockwise to represent their rotated
versions.

* Normally, audio is a one-dimensional
  string of information.

* A single unit of audio information is the
  pressure of the air at a given point in
  time, and these units are placed in a
  sequence.

* Existing audio formats are designed with
  this in mind; they work to compress these
  one-dimensional sequences of numbers.

However, we need something a little more
powerful than that!

* Our audio is two-dimensional; we have two
  time dimensions from which to sample a
  pressure value.

However it turns out we already have a
format for dealing with such two-dimensional
data:

So instead of OGG or WAV, or some other
audio format, the optimal pre-existing
to store audio of Saj is actually PNG.

Now, one may ask "why would you choose a
lossless format?"

-> Audio usually takes up a lot of space and
   pretty much every format for storing it
   is /lossy/.

-> This means that information is lost in
   the encoding.

-> For most cases, this is absolutely fine;
   the change is almost imperceptible.

-> Lossy audio formats are /designed/ to
   make this change imperceptible.

-> Unfortunately, we do not have such a
   design for two-dimensional audio
   information.

-> While we /do/ have lossy audio
   compression for two-dimensional images
   (that's what JPEG does), it would most
   likely lead to strange artifacts on
   audio.

-> Because of that, I opted to choose PNG,
   a lossless format for images.

So, with that said, we can now
look at some waveforms of Saj
speech.

Note that these will be crude
approximations; I don't have the
know-how in order to make a
proper speech synthesizer that
takes into account the variable
lengths of different phonemes,
so instead I've regularized it
so that each phoneme takes the
same amount of time to say.

(oh yeah also I
 forgot to show more
 examples of the
 writing system so
 I'll also do so here)
That whole example phrase from earlier

-> This is a mode of speech in Saj that
   sacrifices information density and
   brevity for clarity.

-> Linear speech actually didn't evolve
   naturally; it was invented for use in
   situations where clarity was more
   important than brevity. (for ex. when
   giving orders)

-> It's used rather rarely and regular
   speech is very much preferred, but it
   is feature of Saj worth mentioning.

* in a way that doesn't sound weird to
  a native speaker.

-> The most natural* way to translate
   long phrases from a linear language
   into Saj.

It collapses subordinate phrases by
adding an "end subordinate phrase"
particle.

Then, the whole phrase is rotated and
the rotated version is placed next to
the non-rotated version.

We can see how it
improves clarity
by looking at a
timeplane.

The time shadows are
pretty big. Normally
not an issue, but
can be.

While we gain an
extra time shadow
in the middle, it
can be disregarded.

The infinite time
shadows are reduced.
